Epstein-Files Declassified Documents Archive

Epstein Flight Log 2013: Five Years After Conviction

By 2013, Jeffrey Epstein had been a convicted sex offender for five years. Yet the flight logs from this year show his aviation operations were as active as ever. The manifests document flights to his island, trips across the United States, and international travel that would later become evidence in federal investigations.

2013 Flight Activity Analysis

The 2013 flight records reveal Epstein's continued extensive use of private aviation. Key patterns emerge from this year's logs:
  • Regular trans-Atlantic flights to European destinations
  • Frequent trips between New York and Florida
  • Consistent island visits throughout the year
  • Mixed passenger loads from business to personal travel
Despite his criminal record, Epstein's lifestyle showed no signs of restriction.

Passenger Records from 2013

The 2013 flight manifests document numerous individuals traveling with Epstein. The records show regular crew members and staff on most flights. Associates and guests appear throughout the year's logs. Some entries record groups traveling together to specific destinations. The names in these logs became subjects of investigation when they were later unsealed.

Destinations and Routes

The 2013 logs show Epstein's aircraft flying to Teterboro, New Jersey as his New York base. Palm Beach, Florida for his mansion visits. St. Thomas, USVI for helicopter transfers to his island. Paris, France and other European cities for international trips. Additional destinations served his various business and personal needs across multiple continents.

Post-Conviction Life in the Air

What's remarkable about the 2013 flight logs is how 'normal' they appear. Epstein was required to register as a sex offender, but there's no indication in the aviation records that his lifestyle changed. He continued to own and operate aircraft. He traveled internationally. He welcomed guests to his properties. The flight logs suggest a man who believed himself above the law - a belief that would prove partly correct until 2019.

Aircraft and Staff in 2013

Epstein's 2013 aviation operations employed multiple aircraft and personnel. The Boeing 727 remained his flagship aircraft for longer flights. Helicopters provided island access from St. Thomas. Pilots, co-pilots, and flight attendants are all documented in the records. The operation represented a substantial ongoing investment in private aviation infrastructure.
The 2013 flight logs demonstrate that Jeffrey Epstein's conviction had little practical effect on his lifestyle. He continued flying extensively, hosting guests, and visiting his island retreat. These records would later help prosecutors build their case and help the public understand how Epstein operated for so long with impunity.
